26pinkmoon: Dear Chimamanda, Words are very light to describe the silence that comes and inhabits us when we lose someone dear, a mother, a father, an aunt, an uncle, a child, a friend... Though words are also so powerful and help us connect, as if by magic. Without having ever met you I feel particularly close to you tonight. Even though I am physically miles and miles away I am standing there, just behind your relatives and friends, close to you, as a fellow human being, as a woman , at a time of mourning for so many of us. At a time when we physically cannot travel to embrace our loved ones and find comfort in their company, nor offer our children the ritual they need, we need, to process the death of their grandfather. At such a time it is ever more important to use words to connect and unite. Thank you for doing that, always. May your aunt rest in peace. Take care. Céline

jewdith.m: My sincere condolence...may God comfort you all in a special way.
fnwanne: @chimamanda_adichie I hope you read this. I have been checking your page since this pandemic broke out to see that all is well with you. I remembered you lived in America and that worried me, the same way it worried me that my sister stays in Lagos where cases rise every now and then. To say I understand or we understand the paranoia you go through would be to tell a lie. Its not something that can be understood. I can't still understand how our world changed so drastically and doing the things that makes us humans, that mark our "Nigerianess" has become like mortal sin. Its sad looking out the window and not seeing people congregated, talking in loud whispers, laughing at God-knows-what. Its hard knowing that I prepared for second semester so bad and yet I'm stuck in my house, waiting, thinking if I'd ever resume school. Automatically, graduation for me has been pushed back and there are many times I feel like crying. And I don't even know the exact reason I'm crying. I don't know if "staying strong" matters now but its so necessary. I hope this passes soon. I hope we somehow return back to the lives we left, I hope your husband and daughter are safe all through. The Lord bless you and keep you. May he lift his light of countenance upon you and give you rest. (These words are from a song I love so much. They give me strength).

kellefatnassi: These are the reminders that we need. In the west, we overemphasize busyness as though it is tantamount to productivity. And as such, we never learned to grieve the big losses as any loss is unacceptable. I’m trying to remind myself on a daily basis that this is not normal, and if my husband is on the other side of the world across closed borders from me, and I wake up sad sometimes or cry myself to sleep, that I shouldn’t berate myself for not having the strength to finish the laundry. I have to tell myself that “this is what I’m doing today,” even if it is nothing. Especially if it is nothing. May God grant all of us peace and healing and I’m sorry for your loss.

jackiepomps: Currently reading Poems, this one by Edna St.Vincent Millay. I shall die, but that is all that I shall do for Death. I hear him leading his horse out of the stall; I hear the clatter on the barn-floor. He is in haste; he has business in Cuba, business in the Balkans, many calls to make this morning. But I will not hold the bridle while he clinches the girth. And he may mount by hinmself: I will not give him a leg up. Though he flick my shoulders with his whip, I will not tell him which way the fox ran. With his hoof on my breast, I will not tell him where the black boy hides in the swamp. I shall die, but that is all that I shall do for Death; I am not on his pay-roll. I will not tell him the whereabout of my friends nor of my enemies either. Though he promise me much, I will not map him the route to any man's door. Am I a spy in the land of the living, that I should deliver men to Death? Brother, the password and the plans of our city are safe with me; never through me Shall you be overcome. 🙏
